citation.article-title: Classification of some coryneform bacteria in a new genus Aureobacterium

p.s: Description of Aureobacterium gen. nov.
Aureobacterium (Aur.e.o.bac.te'ri.um. L. adj. aureus golden; Fr. neut. dim.n. bakterion a small rod; M.L. neut. n. Aureobacterium
In young cultures, small, irregular rods occur; some cells are arranged at an angle to give V-formations.
In older cultures (ca 3 to 7d) rods become shorter but a marked rod-coccus cycle (characteristic of Arthrobacter) is not observed.
Primary branching is uncommon.
Rods are Gram-positive, non-acid fast; metachromatic granules not formed; endospores are not formed.
Growth occurs on suitable solid media in air.
Inhibited by 6.5% NaCl.
Growth range ca 10 to 40°C; optimum temperature ca. 25 to 30°C.
Obligately aerobic.
Slow and weak, oxidative acid production from some carbohydrates.
Nutritionally exacting.
Some organic acids utilized.
Catalase positive.
Non-cellulolytic.
Urease negative.
Cell wall peptidoglycan is based upon D-ornithine (type B2β), [L-Hsr]-D-Glu-Gly-D-Orn; Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
Glycan moiety of peptidoglycan contains glycolyl and acetyl residues.
Do not contain mycolic acids.
The non-hydroxylated fatty acids consist predominantly of anteiso- and iso-methyl branched chains; small amount of straight-chain saturated and traces of monounsaturated acids may be present.
Menaquinones are the sole respiratory quinones.
Major menaquinone isoprenologues are one or more of MK-11, MK-12 and MK-13.
Polar lipids comprise diphoshatidylglycerol and a diglycosylidiacylglycerol.
DNA base compositions in the range 65.4 to 75.6 mol% G + C have been reported.
Type species is Aureobacterium liquefaciens.
